Wonderful, the course taught the practical application of statistical knowledge to conduct epidemiology research.

The course required programs that were not natively available to Macs, requiring a bit of work around. This may be improved by installing all necessary programs on a library computer on campus.

This course equips you with a unique skill set in descriptive and temporospatial biostatistics and epidemiology.  This should be required for doctoral students whose work can directly impact public health policy.  Major strengths include the use of real public health database data, the direct relevance of lecture material to its application in the assignments, and the amazing professor (as instructor and person).  The only weakness is that we did not get a chance to practice with GIS applications, but the professor (at our request) instead chose to use this lecture time to teach us another valuable skill (counterfactual analysis).
I think, overall this class is great. But it's not very friendly for students not in statistical major.
good, interesting
The instructor is clear and concise. He is very willing to explain questions via email or in person and is truly a great mentor.

Prof. Holford is very knowledgeable, approachable, and open to student ideas, discussion, and feedback.  The way he structured the course was logical, and the material (lectures, application examples) was easy to digest and then apply in the homework assignments.  He also made himself available outside of the course for additional guidance on homework and the final project.  Truly, no suggestions for improvement!
Wonderful instructor. Very quick to explain concepts again.
Professor Theodore is very patient and nice. He will repeat every point that might be confusing.
Amazing and supportive professor! He created a safe environment for me to ask questions and was always willing to meet if I had any questions,
very supportive professor

Here, you learn how to analyze disease from a populational level using excel, SAS, and other statistical programs. I recommend the course as it is a true application of public health work in health sciences.

I would ABSOLUTELY recommend this course to anyone in public health (and especially PhD students) whose work has policy implications.  The readily applicable skills acquired through the course in descriptive and temporospatial epidemiology as well as in data visualization and interpretation are second to none.  Prof. Holford is also very kind, approachable, and open to tailoring class structure and discussions to the students' interests and needs.  To anyone considering taking this class: DO IT, and thank me later!
I think this class is highly recommended for student with solid statistical basic and SAS basic.
maybe students need some background on SAS training experience before choosing this course
